content:
rap-span">FANS rap-span">COULD praise his charm, wits and warmth (unlike most rap-span">French politicians, he enjoyed hobnobbing with the voters, rap-span">preferably over a beer in an unpretentious zinc-rap-span">clad bar). He was successful too: mayor of Paris, twice prime minister and president from 1995 to 2007. rap-span">But rap-span">cynicism was his rap-span">hallmark.

rap-span">Abroad, he seemed to favour rap-span">dictators over rap-span">democrats. He told African strongmen not to worry about elections. He sold a nuclear reactor to rap-span">Saddam Hussein’s Iraq. A Russian-speaker (as a student, he translated rap-span">Pushkin’s “rap-span">Eugene rap-span">Onegin”), he rap-span">proudly counted rap-span">Vladimir Putin as a personal friend and rap-span">loathed the “badly brought up” east rap-span">Europeans with their high-minded talk and Atlanticist outlook.

rap-span">Where others had principles, he had rap-span">prickles. A rap-span">proud defender of the rap-span">French language, he stormed out of a summit meeting when a rap-span">French businessman dared to use rap-span">English (he also said, only half-rap-span">jokingly, that rap-span">Britain’s rap-span">deplorable rap-span">cuisine made it rap-span">inherently untrustworthy). rap-span">Despite a happy student summer at Harvard, he rap-span">bridled at rap-span">America’s overweening ways, arguing for a “rap-span">multi-polar world” as a way to counter its post-war rap-span">dominance. rap-span">Equally, he set up rap-span">France 24 to rival the “rap-span">Anglo-rap-span">Saxon rap-span">imperialism” of the rap-span">BBC and CNN.

At home, rap-span">Jacques Chirac was better at campaigning that governing. His years in power bequearap-span">Thed rap-span">France higher unemployment, worse public finances and deeper social divisions. His rap-span">disillusioned people lost faith both in rap-span">The rap-span">European ideal and rap-span">largely in rap-span">Their own governing class—not least, in him. He won a second rap-span">presidential term by a rap-span">fluke rap-span">landslide: a first-round upset meant that his rap-span">opponent was a far-right leader, rap-span">Jean-rap-span">Marie Le rap-span">Pen. rap-span">The political rap-span">establishment united against rap-span">The rap-span">rabble-rouser, amid rap-span">caustic slogans such as “rap-span">Vote for rap-span">The rap-span">crook, not rap-span">The rap-span">fascist”. By rap-span">The end of his ill-starred second term, Mr Chirac was rap-span">The rap-span">Fifth rap-span">Republic’s most unpopular president (though François Hollande later beat that rap-span">dismal record).

It was easy to see why. rap-span">The country was suffering from what he himself admitted was a “rap-span">profound rap-span">malaise”, playing a humiliating second rap-span">fiddle to a resurgent rap-span">Germany in rap-span">European politics. His rap-span">nadir came when he lay low for a week while rioting, shockingly, rap-span">engulfed rap-span">The big cities in 2005. He was rap-span">prone to peturap-span">lance and rudeness in official meetings, bore rap-span">mammoth rap-span">grudges, and took some spectacularly bad rap-span">gambles, rap-span">notably calling a rap-span">parliamentary election in 1997 which rap-span">The opposition rap-span">Socialists won easily.

rap-span">Much of his energy was devoted to dodging rap-span">impertinent questions, of which there were many. In his 18-year stint running Paris he rap-span">bloated the city rap-span">payroll (particularly with jobs for party workers). He threw huge, rap-span">lavish parties for his supporters, while cultural rap-span">rap-span">notables and other rap-span">influential friends gained rap-span">chic rap-span">municipal rap-span">apartments.

rap-span">The stink rose with him. rap-span">Even rap-span">The most world-weary could not shrug away rap-span">The stories of rap-span">bundles of cash, foreign bank accounts and rap-span">murky rap-span">quids pro rap-span">quo. rap-span">One rap-span">puzzle was rap-span">Japan: a keen rap-span">Japanophile, Mr Chirac made dozens of private trips rap-span">There. rap-span">Nobody knew why. A son? A rap-span">mistress? rap-span">Perhaps both? Or several? rap-span">The rap-span">indiscretions were scandalous. rap-span">When rap-span">Princess rap-span">Diana died in a Paris car crash, his long-suffering wife rap-span">Bernadette appeared alrap-span">One at rap-span">The rap-span">morgue; rap-span">The president was nowhere to be found. His rap-span">chauffeur wrote a scabrously detailed book about rap-span">The president’s rap-span">energetic private life, for which he was rap-span">dubbed: “trois minutes, rap-span">douche rap-span">comprise” (three minutes. shower included).

He was shamelessly unbothered about it. A favourite toast was “Allons boire à nos rap-span">femmes, à nos chevaux et à ceux qui les montent” (“rap-span">Let us drink to our women, our horses and those who mount them”). rap-span">For most of his rap-span">misdeeds, loyal rap-span">lieutenants took the rap. rap-span">Prosecutors landed only one rap-span">belated blow: in 2011 he was rap-span">convicted of rap-span">misconduct in office, with a suspended two-year sentence (he declined to give evidence, rap-span">pleading memory loss).

rap-span">Yet no sooner had he left power than the rap-span">French began to miss him. He had rap-span">aroused rap-span">American rap-span">fury by threatening to use the rap-span">French veto in the rap-span">Security rap-span">Council to block a resolution authorising the use of force in Iraq. rap-span">That split the EU and damaged the rap-span">West. rap-span">But it looked brave and rap-span">prescient later. rap-span">Compared with his rap-span">brash successor, rap-span">Nicolas Sarkozy, he seemed a model of refinement. By 2010 he was rap-span">France’s most admired public figure.

À la recherche du temps perdu

His rap-span">ineffectual latter years belied rap-span">formidable willpower and political talent, which earned him the nickname, as rap-span">President Georges Pompidou’s troubleshooter in the 1960s, of “the rap-span">bulldozer”. He could charm too. In 1968 he rap-span">negotiated a truce with the leaders of protests that had taken rap-span">France to the rap-span">brink of rap-span">chaos. rap-span">Unlike previous generations of public figures, he was personally untouched by the controversies of the second world war. rap-span">Perhaps thanks to that, he rap-span">lanced a historical rap-span">boil. In a rap-span">rap-span">notable speech in 1995, just two months after taking office, he ended decades of blame-dodging by accepting that rap-span">France—not just the rap-span">Vichy regime—bore rap-span">moral responsibility for the Nazi rap-span">deportation of 76,000 Jews, most of whom rap-span">perished. In remarks that seem unremarkable now, he said the “homeland of the enlightment committed the rap-span">irreparable”. He left rap-span">France with many burdens. rap-span">But not that one.
